articles.title: How Alzheimer's Disease Makes the Brain Forget
articles.summary: Alzheimer's disease is a sickness that slowly damages the brain, making it hard for people to remember things. Scientists are trying to understand how this happens. They think two things might work together: a protein called amyloid beta and inflammation, which is when the body gets swollen and sore. In a new study, researchers found that both amyloid beta and inflammation can attach to a special part of brain cells called the LilrB2 receptor. This receptor normally helps the brain clean up old connections between cells, which is good for learning. But in Alzheimer's, too much amyloid beta or inflammation tells the brain to remove too many connections, leading to memory loss. The scientists did experiments with mice and discovered that a molecule from inflammation called C4d can also stick to LilrB2 and cause synapse loss. This helps explain why Alzheimer's might trick the brain into erasing its own memories.

articles.title: UK Joins Big Wind Farm Plan with European Friends
articles.summary: The UK is joining a big project with nine other European countries to build many new wind farms in the North Sea. These wind farms will use special underwater cables called interconnectors to share electricity between countries. The government says this will help make energy safer and cheaper by using more wind power instead of fossil fuels like oil and gas. Some people think it could lower bills, but others worry it might make electricity prices go up if wind farms sell power to the highest bidder. The plan aims to be finished by 2050, and it includes countries like Norway, Germany, and the Netherlands. This is the first time wind farms will be directly connected to multiple countries, which could help smooth out energy supply and reduce waste.

articles.title: How Gut Problems Can Lead to Colon Cancer
articles.summary: Scientists have found out why people with a gut disease called IBD get colon cancer more often. IBD makes the gut swollen and sore for a long time. In the study, they looked at a protein called TL1A that is linked to IBD and cancer. This protein tells special immune cells in the gut, called ILC3s, to send signals to the bone marrow. The bone marrow then makes lots of white blood cells called neutrophils. These neutrophils travel to the gut and help tumors grow by damaging cells. The research shows how this chain reaction happens and suggests new ways to stop cancer in people with IBD. They hope this can lead to better treatments and earlier detection.

articles.title: Ancient People Moved a Wild Potato Long Ago
articles.summary: A long time ago, more than 10,000 years back, people in the American Southwest carried a wild potato plant to new places. This plant is called the Four Corners potato, and it is small, tough, and full of good nutrients. Scientists studied old stone tools from 14 different sites where ancient people lived. They found tiny bits of potato starch on tools from nine of these sites, showing that people used the potato for food. This helped the potato spread beyond where it originally grew. The research was led by Lisbeth Louderback from the University of Utah. Today, Indigenous communities, like the Navajo, still know and use this wild potato, keeping their traditions alive. This story shows how ancient people shaped plants and cultures.

articles.title: Scientists Make Tiny Twisty Crystals to Control Electricity
articles.summary: Scientists have found a cool way to build tiny 3D shapes from special crystals to control how electricity flows. They used a special tool called a focused ion beam to carve tiny twisty shapes, like spirals, from a magnetic crystal made of cobalt, tin, and sulfur. These twisty shapes act like tiny switches for electricity, letting it flow more easily in one direction than the other. This could help make future electronics smaller and more powerful. The scientists showed that the shape of the device can change how electricity moves, which is a new idea for designing electronic parts. They hope this method can lead to better memory, logic, and sensing technologies in the future.

articles.title: Did Thomas Edison Make a Super-Thin Material by Accident?
articles.summary: Scientists at Rice University tried an old experiment by Thomas Edison, who invented the light bulb long ago. They wanted to see if he accidentally made a special material called graphene while working on his bulbs. Graphene is very thin and strong, made of carbon atoms, and is used in things like batteries and touchscreens. Edison used bamboo to make the filament, the part that glows in a light bulb, and heated it very hot. The scientists copied his experiment with similar bulbs and found that the filament turned shiny and silver. Using modern tools, they saw it had become graphene in some parts. This doesn't prove Edison made it, but it shows that old experiments can hide surprises. The scientists think other old inventions might have made cool materials too, and we can learn by looking back with new tools.
